statement:
A series $\sum_{i=0}^\infty a_i$ in a Banach space $(V,\|\cdot\|)$ is
iff for every $\varepsilon>0$ there is a number $N\in\mathbb{N}$ such
that $$\|a_{n+1}+a_{n+2}+\cdots+a_{n+p}\|<\varepsilon$$ holds for all
$n>N$ and $p\geq1$.

Proof: {#proof .unnumbered}
------

First define $$s_n:=\sum_{i=0}^n a_i.$$ Now, since $V$ is complete,
$(s_n)$ converges if and only if it is a Cauchy sequence, so if for
every $\varepsilon>0$ there is a number $N$, such that for all $n,m>N$
holds: $$\|s_m-s_n\|<\varepsilon.$$ We can assume $m>n$ and thus set
$m=n+p$. The series is iff
$$\|s_{n+p}-s_n\|=\|a_{n+1}+a_{n+2}+\cdots+a_{n+p}\|<\varepsilon.$$
